comment.author: 7806261@N06
comment._content: That's Shed 14 South Wharf, Melbourne. Robison Bros ( who cast the Bourke and Wills statue) were located in South Melbourne on the south side of the river.

comment.author: 7806261@N06
comment._content: emhs.org.au/catalogue/emdf0042 Both buildings, and the small shed with the life buoy can be seen in the aerial on the link. If this was a visit around 1921, then the vessel may have been under arrest. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/63652787?searchTerm=Fort...

comment.author: 39191857@N05
33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/miniop] Thanks for the location id! We've updated our records. There is a later image at the State Library of Victoria showing a spruced-up Robison Bros building. Interesting article re the vessel's 'arrest' - certainly bears further investigation.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 30243539@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] some more historical info: the Dutch equivalent of 'Schooner' (schoener) refers to a fore-and-aft sailing plan where the aft mast is at least as tall as the foremast.

comment.author: 29050464@N06
comment._content: Fine old photo. Added to commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Schooners Converted in 1920 from a steamship. Ferris-type hull. Ref: The Schooner: Its Design and Development from 1600 to the Present By David R. MacGregor, p.158 Thanks for posting these!

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/29050464@N06] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/minusvanbaalen] Thanks for your comments - its great to share these lovely old images :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: I think you can probably refine the location even further - if you look at www.whatsthatpicture.com/flickr/commons/photo.php?photo_i... and zoom in where the red pin is, you'll see the map says 'Shed 14'. Of course that presumes there's not been any renumbering since.
